data.text: Damp and Smelly Sleeping Bag after Camping
so i’m fairly new to camping. after my first night i woke up damn near soaked and my sleeping bag now smells pretty bad. i’m just wondering if this is normal and something to get used too. thanks.

Did you sleep outdoors and get soaked with dew? That is definitely an issue in damp areas. If it is not too hot, a light tarp can serve as ground cloth and cover, and in case of rain a fair shelter. Otherwise .... you need to cook the sleeping bag---in the sun if you have time, or take it to a laundromat and run it through the dryer on whatever setting it recommends, to kill the mold and stuff. It is also possible to loosely lash it to your load, exposed, to get a little sun and fresh air on it .... hope you don't get caught in a sudden rain shower.

data.text: Synthetic fibers on my skin always makes me stink as well as the synthetic thing I was wearing. However I can wear wool clothing every day for a week while working, exercising, whatever, and I won’t smell at all. So I wear wool t shirts, sweaters, etc. to latch the season and keep a barrier between my skin and the tech fabrics that make up so much of my camping setup. Maybe it is something similar with you. As for wet bag, not normal and not something to come to expect. Ventilation is hugely important in tents, especially as it gets cooler outside. Condensation can produce tons of water.

data.text: Trees reduce radiative cooling, as do clouds, so the tent fabric does not get so cold.
data.author: David Backhouse

data.text: Something to do with radiation (being trapped or reflected). Also the same effect can occur to some extent when camping by a cliff or a big rock, but that's not advisable as there's a higher risk of getting "stoned," LOL. Under trees you also have to mind (check above with a glance or two) for "widow-makers," but the risk is minimal unless you have very strong winds. And you will notice a lot more condensation and dew in the morning after very clear (no clouds) nights in wide open spaces (where presumably the radiation escapes more freely), and especially on green grass (they give off more moisture than dry grass, hay or pine needles, which are my favorite).

data.author: Jake Klamerus

data.text: #1 You may have gotten hot & sweated, meaning your bag insulates too well for the temperature you were sleeping in. You may need more ventilation. #2 You may have exhaled into your sleeping bag & the moisture condensed on the outer surface of the bag, meaning you need to exhale outside the bag. #3 Your body may release a lot of moisture (apart from your breath), meaning you may need more layers - thinner layers - instead of fewer thicker layers - so the moisture doesn't hit such a radical temperature transition all at once. You may want to replace your down bag with a PUFF bag. Down insulates well while dry, but loses all insulation effect when it gets wet. Polyester Ultra Fiber Fill (PUFF) doesn't insulate quite as well as down when its dry, but also doesn't depend on dryness so it ends up insulating much better than down in damp conditions. You may want to transition from a single thick bag to multiple thin bags that can be added or removed, like layering your clothes: wicking layer, radiant reflecting layer, insulation layer, wind-breaking layer, etc. Your smelly bag needs sunlight & ventilation (& maybe Febreeze too).
